titles.alternate: Regina man charged in human smuggling investigation
titles.seo: Regina man charged in connection with human smuggling investigation

mt_seo_description: A Regina man is facing charges in connection with an alleged human smuggling operation that the RCMP intercepted in April.Â
mt_seo_title: Regina man charged in connection with human smuggling investigation
_pn_skedline: More charges in human smuggling case.
_pn_title_alternate: Regina man charged in human smuggling investigation

content_elements.content: Deported from the U.S. then arrested in Saskatchewan, a Regina man charged in an alleged human smuggling operation is free again after he was released on conditions Wednesday.
Victor Omoruyi , 41, appeared in a Saskatoon courtroom after his arrest Tuesday afternoon at the Saskatoon International Airport by the RCMP Integrated Border Enforcement Team.

Omoruyi is charged with one count of human smuggling and one count of aiding or abetting. The Crown consented to his release on a $3,000 cash recognizance. Under conditions of release, he is not contact two named individuals, must maintain a curfew and his Regina residence, and can’t leave Saskatchewan without permission from a bail officer. His next appearance is in Estevan Provincial Court on Dec. 4.

The charges stem from a four-month-long investigation, dubbed Project Fadduce. Nine Nigerian citizens and asylum-seekers were intercepted while crossing into Canada on April 14 between the North Portal and Northgate ports of entry at the Saskatchewan-U.S. border.
His wife Michelle Omoruyi, 43, was also charged at that time with human smuggling and conspiracy to commit human smuggling. The charges are still before Estevan Provincial Court.
In a related matter, Victor Omoruyi was sentenced in August to six months in jail after pleading guilty in a North Dakota district court last spring to transporting an illegal alien.

U.S. court documents signed by border agents say he was arrested April 14 after an SUV was stopped south of the border. They say Omoruyi told border officers he was going to meet friends and shop in Minot N.D. They say authorities started watching him because he was identified “as a human smuggler that has previously provided transportation … for individuals who have then entered into Canada illegally.”

The affidavit details how border agents followed Omoruyi for several hours. At one point, five adults and four children left a hotel and got into Omoruyi’s vehicle, the U.S. documents say, adding that an RCMP officer saw the nine passengers walk north, through an open field, to Canada and make it to a vehicle waiting to pick them up.
(with files from Canadian Press and the Saskatoon StarPhoenix)

_pn_title_alternate: All visitors to city hall (even Joe Biden) must now sign in
pn_featured_image_caption: Mayor ValÃ©rie Plante, leaning forward at left, attends her administration's first executive-committee meeting at city hall on Wednesday.

content_elements.content: She pegs herself as the mobility mayor, but Valérie Plante did not commit to increasing Montreal’s contribution to public transit agencies in the 2018 budget.

“I have always said our administration will be about mobility, and the (Société de transport de Montréal) is the main organ that we work with, so it will be important to review their budget and look at their priorities, and we have already started to do that,” Plante said Wednesday morning.

Plante was equally non-committal when asked about her promised congestion squad, to deal with traffic jams in the city. A major water-main repair began on Wednesday near the Jacques-Cartier Bridge and has caused major traffic jams in that part of the city. The work is expected to be completed by mid-December.

“We don’t want people stuck in their cars for hours, so we have to find a solution,” Plante told reporters at city hall, adding that a traffic jam like that shows the necessity of creating the congestion squad, which would help during major roadwork projects.
Plante made the comments on the heels of her first executive committee meeting, and as the new council begins to set its agenda for the next four years.

She said she is facing challenges fulfilling her electoral promises while respecting the ability of Montrealers to pay their tax bills. Plante has promised to hold taxes to within the rate of inflation.
That’s one of the reasons Plante has decided to table the city’s 2018 budget on Jan. 10, 2018, instead of in December, as is customary.

“The challenge is, how do we make sure we respect Montreal’s financial capacity while putting more resources into mobility and housing, which are really expensive,” Plante said. “There are some measures where we would wish to push forward right now. It is a difficult balance.”
Plante said one of the first acts in her mandate will be to make city hall more transparent.
Addressing the executive committee earlier Wednesday, Plante said all visitors to city hall for business with elected officials will once again have to sign a register.
In the last months of Denis Coderre’s mandate, people visiting the mayor no longer had to sign in.
In the next few days, Plante said, she will reveal details of her agenda, and they will be published online.
It will be a busy time for Plante, with her taking several trips in her capacity as mayor. Next week, she will be in Toronto for a meeting of Canada’s big-city mayors.
Next month, she will visit Chicago for a
global summit of mayors on climate change
, and then head to Paris for the
One Planet Summit

titles.main: Analyze This: Canadiens' Shea Weber at his best alongside Victor Mete
titles.seo: Analyze This: Canadiens' Shea Weber at his best alongside Victor Mete

authors.name: Marc Dumont, Special to The Gazette

excerpt: Habs' top defenceman is saddled with dragging his partners up to a respectable level.

image.title: 112217-no_object-1123_spt_col_analyzethis-W.jpg
image.caption: Montreal Canadiens' Shea Weber, left, celebrates his goal against the Arizona Coyotes with team-mates Karl Alzner and Tomas Plekanec during second period in Montreal on Nov. 16, 2017.
image.description:
MONTREAL, QUE.: NOVEMBER  16, 2017 -- Montreal Canadiens Shea Weber, left, celebrates his goal against the Arizona Coyotes with team-mates Karl Alzner and Tomas Plekanec during second period of National Hockey League game in Montreal Thursday November 16, 2017. (John Mahoney / MONTREAL GAZETTE) ORG XMIT: 59738 - 9649
John Mahoney, Montreal Gazette

content_elements.content: When the Canadiens traded P.K. Subban to the Nashville Predators for Shea Weber in a blockbuster deal on June 29, 2016, the word on the street was that they had acquired a rock-steady defenceman who would solidify the blue line and become an imposing presence on the team.

To his credit, Weber has played well throughout his tenure in Montreal. His strength lies in denying controlled entries into the defensive zone, as well as using his heavy shot to terrorize goalies on the power play.

Given that the Canadiens acquired a player who was older than the one they sent to Nashville, logic would dictate that they should have insulated him with talent in order to get the best from their top-pairing defenceman. However, that hasn’t been the case.

Other than when he was paired with Andrei Markov at the end of last season, Weber has been tasked with dragging his defensive partners up to a respectable level. That’s not a knock on the Canadiens’ defensive personnel — there’s only so much a player can do with limited talent — and no player will refuse an opportunity to play on the top pair alongside Weber. Rather, the issue lies in the players the coaches have to work with — the players general manager Marc Bergevin has assembled to form his defensive core.

In 2016, Weber spent the majority of his shifts alongside three players: Alexei Emelin (1,045 minutes), Markov (466 minutes) and Nathan Beaulieu (247 minutes). He did an admirable job keeping Emelin and Beaulieu above water, but his numbers improved significantly once he played alongside another legitimate top-pairing defenceman.

As the accompanying chart shows, Weber played his best hockey with Markov, and though he maintained respectable numbers with Emelin, controlling a little over 50 per cent of the shots is not what you want to see from your highest paid blue-liner.

This season, the underlying numbers have looked good alongside two players in particular. Weber has produced very respectable numbers when paired with rookie Victor Mete (53 CF%, 60 HDCF%) and Jordie Benn (55 CF%, 70 HDCF%), but the same cannot be said when he’s playing with Karl Alzner (46 CF%, 36 HDCF%).

Head coach Claude Julien uses the Alzner-Weber pairing in a lot of defensive-zone starts, and their quality of competition is a little higher than when Weber plays with Mete or Benn, but that pairing gets outshot and, more importantly, out-chanced by a significant margin. For $12.5 million worth of salary cap (18 per cent of the team’s total), you don’t expect a pairing to give up just under 65 per cent of the high-danger shots while they’re on the ice. It’s simply unacceptable, and it doesn’t happen while Weber is paired with other defenders.
In fact, there’s not much positive when we examine Alzner’s numbers so far this season, but we’ll circle back to that another week.

Related

  • P.K. Subban, Alexei Emelin reunited on Predators' blue line
  • Canadiens promote Laval Rocket defenceman Jakub Jerabek
  • In the Habs' Room: Bad habits continue to bite Canadiens
  • About last night ... A good effort, but Stars shine through
  • Analyze This: Canadiens' lack of fourth-line punch KOs offence

It’s understandable that Julien doesn’t particularly trust Mete to play important minutes, but the stats indicate that Weber does much better with Mete at his side rather than Alzner — and even more so when it comes to Benn.

Ideally, none of these players would be playing big minutes on the Canadiens’ top pairing. That’s not to say they haven’t been playing well, they have. But you’d be hard pressed to pencil in Benn or Mete as a legitimate top-pairing defenceman in the NHL. They’re playing above their pay grade, and while that’s a boon for Bergevin, it points to a clear lack of foresight when assembling the team’s defence.
This brings us back to the original issue. Weber is being used to elevate his defensive partners instead of being used alongside a top-pairing defender who compliments his style of play.

This summer, Weber will still have eight years left on a contract that pays him over $7.8 million per season. Unless the Canadiens expect to somehow get great value from him by the 2025-26 season, they’d be wise to find someone to fill the glaring hole at left defence on the No. 1 pairing. It’s beyond overdue at this point.

The Canadiens are supposed to be contenders, especially during Year 6 of Bergevin’s five-year plan. If they’re not contenders — and that appears to be the case — they’d be better off trading Weber. He is regarded as one of the best defencemen in the NHL by many general managers, but he’s on the wrong side of 30 in a league that’s quickly transitioning toward youth over experience.
In the meantime, it would be wise to keep Weber away from Alzner, and start trusting Mete and Weber to take on more important assignments.

titles.main: Man, 33, charged with second-degree murder in stabbing outside Shepherds of Good Hope
titles.seo: Arrest made in fatal stabbing of Adrian Johnson

authors.bio:
Police and crime reporter
syogaretnam@postmedia.com 
twitter.com/shaaminiwhy
authors.name: Shaamini Yogaretnam

image.title: Fabebook photo of Damien Dubien1123 arrest
image.caption: Damien Dubien is charged with second-degree murder in the killing of Adrian Johnson.

content_elements.content: An argument between Adrian Johnson and his killer escalated into a fight early Saturday morning that would end with Johnson knifed and begging for help outside the Shepherds of Good Hope.

Homicide detectives have charged Damien Dubien, 33, with second-degree murder in the fatal stabbing. Dubien, wearing a green hoodie and resting his head in his cuffed hands, leaned against a counter as he made a video appearance in court Wednesday.
Police arrested Dubien just after midnight Tuesday night on Cummings Avenue in the city’s east end, nearly four days after Johnson’s homicide.

Johnson, 45, was found bleeding outside the Shepherds of Good Hope in the ByWard Market early Saturday morning. Witnesses said he collapsed into the hands of a panhandler, and was pronounced dead in hospital around 5 a.m.
Police believe the fight between two men began inside a residence on Murray Street. They took the fight outside, where Johnson was stabbed in the chest.
Dubien, a convicted drug dealer, is known to police. He also has a conviction for assault in March of this year.

Johnson was described by those who knew him as a veteran of the streets of Lowertown, who was kind but made several enemies after questionable drug deals. Those who knew him said he had a reputation for ripping people off and was known as a “bully.”

A former colleague at an Ottawa restaurant, who asked to remain anonymous, said that “in a life gone by,” Johnson had been “an ambitious, driven and generous human being” who attended local schools, played competitive sports and later supported his family as a head chef.
Johnson was among the people profiled in a report by this newspaper on the scourge of fentanyl on downtown streets.
Johnson described himself as someone suffering from addiction and mental health issues.
Dubien was ordered not to contact a lengthy list of witnesses in the case. He is next scheduled to appear in court on Dec. 6.
Johnson’s death is the city’s 13th homicide of the year.
syogaretnam@postmedia.com
twitter.com/shaaminiwhy

content_elements.content: In America, Black Friday falls on the day after Thanksgiving. But in Canada, where we celebrated Thanksgiving a month ago, Black Friday is probably better described as the Friday before Cyber Monday. With Christmas just around the corner, and no more major North American holidays standing between now and then, the holiday shopping season begins in earnest this weekend.

To stir your holiday shopping spirit, retailers all across Metro Vancouver are promising deals upon deals. We’ve done our best to round them all up so you can shop with purpose and maximize your savings.
Please check back often, as we will be updating this list as new deals are made public.

pn_featured_image_caption: Steve Mason gets the call tonight versus the Los Angeles Kings.

content_elements.content: LOS ANGELES – Steve Mason makes his first start in five games as the Winnipeg Jets attempt to bounce back from a 5-3 loss to the Nashville Predators.
Mason is coming off one of his strongest showings of the season, a 29-save effort in a victory over the Arizona Coyotes, as the Jets continue a four-game road trip against the Los Angeles Kings.

“We’ve liked the way (Mason) has trended. He deserved to get back in after his last game,” said Jets head coach Paul Maurice. “(It’s also related to) the volume of games. We’ve got four here in six (days) on the road, but they’re wrapped in home (games) with heavy, heavy travel. Having two fresh goalies for the next two or three weeks is going to be really, really important.”
The Jets remain in second place in the Central Division and haven’t lost consecutive games in regulation since starting the campaign 0-2.
It was not the start to the season Mason had envisioned when signing a two-year deal with the Jets on July 1.
Mason was pulled in his first start and started 0-3-1 before finally picking up his first victory of the season against the Coyotes on Nov. 11.
But he’s worked hard to stay sharp and waited for his opportunity as Connor Hellebuyck played well.
By getting the start tonight, Mason sets up to play again either Friday against the Anaheim Ducks or Saturday against the San Jose Sharks.

“(Mason) has relied on his experience as a pro. He’s got a routine, he’s worked hard and he understands it – it’s been an easier situation, if it can be that for a veteran guy watching – because he understands the quality of (Hellebuyck’s) work,” said Maurice. “He gets it. He stays ready and he knows he’s going to go back in and he’s going to play. He put in a lot of extra work, a lot of extra work and some detail stuff.”
In Monday’s loss, the Jets were outscored 3-0 during the second period and made a game of it in the third but came up short.

“The last game it was the second period where we had some breakdowns that cost us,” said Jets centre Bryan Little. “Tonight, we want to play our typical game for 60 minutes. Staying out of the box would definitely help. We’ve been really good at regrouping after losses this year and we look to keep that going.
“No one is hitting the panic button.”
The Kings (12-7-2) currently lead the Pacific Division by one point over the Vegas Golden Knights, but have only one win during their past six games.

“The Kings are off to a great start and they’ve seemed to kind of slow down,” said Jets centre Adam Lowry. “If you look at the way (Anze) Kopitar and Dustin Brown (are playing), they found their game after struggling a little bit points-wise last year. They have a lot of speed up front and they have one of the best defencemen in the league in Drew Doughty. He plays basically half the game. He’s up the ice and creates a lot of chances for them and he’s really good defensively.
“The biggest thing (for the Kings) this year is they’ve got a healthy Jonathan Quick. He gives you a chance to win every night. He’s playing really well.”
It is sure to be a special night for the Lowry family, since Adam’s father Dave will be behind the Kings bench as an assistant coach on the staff of John Stevens.

“It was nice to get the day off (Tuesday) here and get to see my parents’ new neighbourhood and spend some time with them,” said Adam Lowry. “It’s not too often the last few years, especially with him coaching in the Western Hockey League (with the Victoria Royals), I haven’t seen a whole ton during the hockey season.

“It was nice to see them, get a home-cooked meal. We talked about where my game is at and things like that and just about how he and my mom are enjoying it down here in L.A., with where they’re living and all of the activities that come with being in a nice climate. We didn’t talk much about the game. We’ll just enjoy battling against each other tonight and hopefully, we get this one.”
The Jets aren’t making any lineup changes and are reverting back to their standard lines up front after Maurice did some juggling during the third period on Monday.

“I don’t think switching it in the third had a whole lot to do with us playing better in the third,” said Maurice. “(The Predators) sat back and we got back to our game. I wouldn’t take 20 minutes and have it overshadow the really good game they played the game before (against) New Jersey, where I liked the way the lines ran.
“We got behind it and I wanted to take a look at some different things. When you get into a game like that, you’re looking just to try some things, maybe not even for that night but moving forward.”
Here’s how both teams are expected to start tonight:
WinnipegÂ Jets
Forwards
Kyle Connor-Mark Scheifele-Blake Wheeler
Nikolaj Ehlers-Bryan Little-Patrik Laine
Andrew Copp- Adam Lowry-Brandon Tanev
Mathieu Perreault-Matt Hendricks-Joel Armia
Defence
Josh Morrissey -Jacob Trouba
Ben Chiarot-Dustin Byfuglien
Dmitry Kulikov-Tyler Myers
Goalies
Steve Mason
Connor Hellebuyck
Los Angeles Kings
Forwards
Alex Iafallo-Anze Kopitar-Dustin Brown
Tanner Pearson-Adrian Kempe-Tyler Toffoli
Andy Andreoff-Nick Shore-Trevor Lewis
Jussi Jokinen-Nic Dowd-Johnny Brodzinski
Defence
Derek Forbort-Drew Doughty
Jake Muzzin-Christian Folin
Kurtis Macdermid-Alex Martinez
Goalies
Jonathan Quick
Darcy Kuemper

Toronto Argonauts arrive for Grey Cup practice to the sound of gunshots: Hot Buttered Post for Wednesday, Nov. 22
titles.alternate: Hot Buttered Post: Argos arrive at Grey Cup to the sound of gunshots

excerpt: Plus: Russia loses two more Olympic medals, the Hamburglar returns to the NHL and the Jaguars sit out yet another American Thanksgiving

image.title: FBO CFL Grey Cup Argos 20171122
image.caption: Toronto Argonauts players practice during Grey Cup Week in Ottawa on Nov. 22.

content_elements.content: Your midday sports snack.
Toast points

• Gunshots were reportedly fired near the Toronto Argonauts’ Grey Cup practice facility in Ottawa as the team filed off the bus this morning. Players and onlookers said they heard five loud pops and saw police officers with their weapons drawn on the far side of Highway 417, which is adjacent to the field at the University of Ottawa. “I stepped off the bus and heard some loud bangs,” said quarterback Ricky Ray, adding that he wondered if he should return to the bus.
Ottawa Police confirmed a vehicle had been stopped in the area, but didn’t provide additional details. Later reports indicate the police had fired rubber bullets.

• Toronto FC withstood suspensions to star strikers Sebastian Giovinco and Jozy Altidore in scrounging their way to a 0-0 road draw in the first leg of the MLS Eastern Conference final last night. Both players should be back when Toronto hosts Columbus in the return leg next Wednesday. The Eastern champion will likely meet Seattle in the final; the Sounders went two road goals up on Houston with a 2-0 win in Game 1 of the Western final.

• The IOC today banned four Russian skeleton Olympians for doping violations, including the men’s gold medallist and women’s bronze medallist at Sochi 2014. The decision retroactively strips Alexander Tretyakov and Elena Nikitina of their medals and prohibits them and their counterparts from competing at future Games. The committee’s sport-by-sport inquisition into Russia’s state-sponsored doping scheme has now resulted in 10 bans, including those of six cross-country skiers announced earlier this month.

• More fun with NHL scoring this season: The league reports that five games have had one period with seven combined goals and that four of them have occurred in the last nine days. The latest was the third period of St. Louis’ 8-3 win over Edmonton last night. The teams combined for seven goals to pad a 4-0 Blues lead after two periods.

• The Hamburglar is back in the NHL. Andrew Hammond, who led the Ottawa Senators on a wildly improbable run to the playoffs in 2014-15 season but had become extraneous in the organization, was recalled to the NHL by the Colorado Avalanche on Wednesday. Hammond joined the Avalanche as part of the Matt Duchene trade this month. He’ll back up Jonathan Bernier while Semyon Varlamov gets over an illness.

content_elements.title: Andrew Hammond
content_elements.caption: In this March 15, 2015 file photo, Ottawa Senators goalie Andrew Hammond holds a hamburger after beating the Philadelphia Flyers in a shootout.
content_elements.shortcode: [caption id="attachment_727395" align="aligncenter" width="640"] In this March 15, 2015 file photo, Ottawa Senators goalie Andrew Hammond holds a hamburger after beating the Philadelphia Flyers in a shootout.[/caption]

content_elements.content: • John Coppolella, the former Atlanta Braves general manager who resigned las month because of a looming scandal over the illegal signing of international free agents, was given a lifetime ban by commissioner Rob Manfred on Tuesday afternoon. He joins a select list of people given a lifetime ban from major league baseball, headlined by Pete Rose, and the Black Sox eight, including Shoeless Joe Jackson.

Before last year, no one had been permanently banned from baseball since Rose in 1988. Coppolella is the second team executive handed such a punishment this year. In January, former Cardinals scouting director Chris Correa was banned as a part of the scandal in which the Cardinals hacked the Houston Astros’ scouting servers. Former New York Mets pitcher Jenrry Mejia was banned in 2016 for testing positive for performance-enhancing drugs for the third time.

Former Blue Jays general manager Alex Anthopoulos was hired this month to take over as general manager and head of the Braves baseball operations. The Braves found out yesterday that they will lose 13 of the prospects signed by Coppolella as punishment for the signing scandal. The 13 players, including top-40 prospect Kevin Maitan, will become free agents.

• It caught our eye that British investor Amanda Staveley is leading the group looking to buy Newcastle United. Women are rarely the face of an effort to purchase a sports franchise, although there are women who are or have been owners; most often, the controlling interest is passed to women through inheritance, like the Lakers’ Jeannie Buss or the Detroit Lions’ Martha Firestone Ford. Oddly, Staveley is also in the middle of a $1-billion civil suit against Barclays, which is the lead sponsor of the Premier League.

• For now, at least, Nathan Peterman will not get a chance to atone for his historically repugnant debut as a starting NFL quarterback. Bills head coach Sean McDermott returned the starter’s reins to Tyrod Taylor this morning after Peterman threw five interceptions in the first half of a blowout loss to the Chargers on Sunday. The Bills (5-5) are only one spot out of the AFC’s current playoff lineup despite losing three straight games. They face the 6-4 Chiefs next Sunday.

content_elements.content: Nutritional information

Thursday marks the 50th anniversary of the Dallas Cowboys’ participation in the NFL’s annual U.S. Thanksgiving Day tradition of games. Dallas will meet the Los Angeles Chargers at AT&T Stadium in the second game of the day, looking to improve on its 30-18-1 record on the fourth Thursday of November.

The Detroit Lions have an even longer history on the day, with tomorrow’s early game against the Minnesota Vikings marking their 73rd Thanksgiving Day game. Detroit’s record is 34-36-2, although the Lions have won their last four after a nine-game losing streak.

Below is a chart showing which of the current 32 NFL franchises have played at least twice on Thanksgiving Day since 1940, although the tradition goes back to the 1920s, before the formal launch of the NFL. The list also includes games played by American Football League franchise before the two leagues merged in 1970.

The Packers are the team with the third-most Thanksgiving games because they were the Lions’ opponent for 13 straight years from 1951-63 and have been frequently scheduled as the Lions’ opponent more recently (six times since 2001). Despite being traditional division rivals, Minnesota and Detroit will meet for just the fifth time, although that’s enough to make the list of most common Thanksgiving matchups.

The NFL added a third game to the slate in 2006, which has given other franchises an opportunity to get in on the fun. Although the Lions and Cowboys own 123 of the 160 games played on Thanksgiving since 1940, 15 other teams have had at least one holiday home game, although many of those games were during the days of the AFL. Washington gets its first home Thanksgiving game in tomorrow’s late game after being the road team in nine previous holiday appearances.
The Jacksonville Jaguars are the only team that hasn’t played on the holiday.

Poor, poor Edmonton.

content_elements.content: At nationalpost.com
• The most audacious experiment of the NBA season is underway in Toronto —
and so far, itâs going well

. New York Times reporter Scott Cacciola ventured north for this feature on the Raptors’ revamped offence, detailing how the team’s existing personnel has stopped chucking inefficient midrange jumpers and learned to move the ball, cut to the hoop and launch a whole lot of threes. (Will they stick to the new plan come playoff time? Stay tuned.)
• The Blue Jays swung a trade for Gift Ngoepe this week because they think he’s one of the best defensive infielders in baseball, writes Steve Buffery. But they’re
also enamoured with his backstory

. Ngoepe, whose childhood home was a baseball clubhouse in Randburg, South Africa, became the first African-born major leaguer in more than a century when the Pirates summoned him to play 28 games this past season.

mt_seo_title: Giants expect to lose Roman to Slovaks for world junior tournament
pni_headline: Giants expect to lose Roman to Slovaks for world junior tournament
pn_featured_image_caption: Milos Roman has 22 points, including six goals, in 23 games for the Giants this season.
_pn_skedline: (SENT TO SAXO: Dawson) Slovak centre Milos Roman has played so well early on the Vancouver Giants that it's easy to wonder how the team might look without him next month assuming he gets the call to play in the world juniors

content_elements.content: Milos Roman has played so well so far for the Vancouver Giants that you can find yourself pondering already how the team might look next month assuming the rookie centre is away at the world junior tournament.

Giants general manager Glen Hanlon says he has yet to hear from the Slovaks about Roman in regards to the Dec. 26 to Jan. 5 competition in Buffalo, but he fully expects Roman to represent his country.

Roman was part of the Slovak entry in last season’s world juniors in Montreal and Toronto, and the 18-year-old has been manning the middle on Vancouver’s top line for much of the season, playing between over-age wingers Ty Ronning and Brad Morrison.

There has been loads of chatter about his mature two-way game, but Roman was also leading WHL rookies in scoring as of Wednesday morning. Heading into Vancouver’s meeting at the Langley Events Centre with the Lethbridge Hurricanes on Wednesday evening, Roman had 22 points, including six goals, in 23 games.
Roman’s teammates with the Slovaks at the last world juniors included winger Radovan Bondra, who was a member of the Giants at the time. Bondra was traded to the Prince George Cougars in January.
Those world juniors opened on Boxing Day as per usual. Bondra left the Giants on Dec. 16 for a training camp.
Based on that timeline, Roman could miss eight Giants games with these world juniors.

“He plays a lot of critical minutes for us, including on our power play and our penalty kill,” Giants coach Jason McKee said. “You take that out of your line-up, it definitely puts a big gap there. Some of our other players are going to have to step up and take those minutes.”

Roman’s the best Vancouver candidate to go to Buffalo. Giants left winger Tyler Benson, 19, was invited to Hockey Canada’s summer camp, but the Edmonton Oilers prospect didn’t take part due to two off-season sports hernia surgeries. He was also named to Team WHL for the CIBC Canada Russia Series, but pulled out of the two games because he had just been activated from the disabled list and wanted to focus on playing for Vancouver.
New York Rangers draft pick Ronning and Morrison are too old to take part.

Vancouver’s schedule during the world junior stretch includes three games against the Prince George Cougars, one of the clubs they will be fighting with for a playoff spot. Prince George could well be missing Dennis Cholowski, since the Detroit Red Wings defence prospect from Langley is a strong bet to make Team Canada.
The Giants also have a pair of contests during that span with the Everett Silvertips. Everett is expected to be without starting goalie Carter Hart, who made Team Canada last year.

A Buffalo stint would cut into Roman’s statistics with the Giants, although Vancouver’s Marek Tvrdon still managed to lead WHL rookies in scoring in 2011-12 despite playing in the world juniors with the Slovaks that season. Tvrdon, a left winger who was 18 at the time, had 74 points, including 31 goals, in 60 regular season games.
Other Giants to lead WHL rookies in scoring include Kevin Connauton, a defenceman who topped freshman in 2009-10 when he put up 72 points, highlighted by 24 goals, in 69 games.

The initial Vancouver plan this season had been to play Morrison between Benson and Ronning on the No. 1 line, but Benson wasn’t ready to start the campaign. Roman, Vancouver’s choice at No. 6 overall in this summer’s CHL Import Draft, was quickly moved into frontline duty and has looked at home ever since.
He received a ‘B’ rating from Central Scouting in their November Players To Watch list, which means they have him pegged to be a second or third-round pick in the 2018 NHL Draft.

“There’s never a shortage of ‘try’ out there from Milos,” McKee explained. “He’s very good in own zone. He’s very advanced in that way. He understands the places to be. His stick and his instincts are tremendous, and all in three zones really.”
It’s hard to guess now what McKee might do in the event of a Roman absence. He could try Benson with Ronning and Morrison, although Benson has chemistry currently with James Malm and Brendan Semchuk.

mt_seo_keywords: cat abuse, duncan, gigi, shaved, drugged, snapchat, Vancouver Island, rcmp, arrest, spca
mt_seo_description: Mounties have arrested a 20-year-old Duncan man who allegedly shaved and drugged a cat and posted the video on Snapchat.
_pn_skedline: Mounties have arrested a 20-year-old Duncan man who allegedly shaved and drugged a cat and posted the video on Snapchat.
mt_seo_google_news_meta: cat abuse, duncan, gigi, shaved, drugged, snapchat, Vancouver Island, rcmp, arrest, spca

content_elements.content: Mounties have arrested a 20-year-old Duncan man who allegedly shaved and drugged a cat and posted the video on Snapchat.
North Cowichan/Duncan RCMP said Wednesday morning they are investigating a case of animal cruelty. One man has been arrested and charges are being considered against other youth who were involved.

Sharline Haglund’s daughter was sent Snapchat videos of the family’s cat, Gigi, being abused early Tuesday morning. The videos were sent with the caption, “Your cat loves Molly,” referring to the party drug MDMA.

Gigi was missing until Tuesday night. Haglund said the cat was found on Sherman Road. The cat’s fur was shaved and “666” was written on her ear. The cat’s fur was discoloured with possible bleach spots.
Gigi is being treated at Prevost Veterinary clinic in Duncan.
The SPCA has is also involved in the investigation.

content_elements.shortcode: [caption id="attachment_703747" align="alignright" width="294"] Gigi the cat is now recovering at a Duncan-area veterinary clinic after its fur was shaved and 666 was written on its ear. The catâs fur was discoloured, possibly with bleach.[/caption]

content_elements.title: Screen Shot 2017-11-22 at 1.03.20 PM

content_elements.content: “The public is encouraged to let the police complete the investigation and respect the judicial process,” said Island district RCMP spokeswoman Cpl. Tammy Douglas, who warned people not to resort to vigilante justice. “We are always concerned when people decide to bypass law enforcement and take matters into their own hands. When that happens there is a risk that investigations can be jeopardized and key evidence can be lost.”
In a post on Facebook, Haglund said she’s concerned not only about the animal cruelty, but about the cyberbullying directed at her daughter.
Click here to read more stories from The Victoria Times Colonist.

_pn_skedline: Ottawa police are searching for a missing 14-year-old girl who hasn't been seen in nearly two weeks.

content_elements.content: Ottawa police are searching for a missing 14-year-old girl who hasn’t been seen in nearly two weeks.
Michelle Tait is Indigenous and was last seen in the South Keys area on Nov. 11. Police say Tait may have also been spotted in Gatineau.
Tait stands 5-1 and weighs 110 lbs. When last seen, she was wearing a black winter jacket, black pants and brown Ugg boots. She was also wearing a bandana.
She has short dark hair and brown eyes.

Anyone with information about her whereabouts is asked to call Ottawa Police at 613-236-1222. If you have information that could help investigators, but don’t know where Tait is, please contact the Ottawa Police Service Missing Persons Unit at 613-236-1222, extension 2355.

image.caption: The Ottawa Police Service is asking for assistance to locate missing female Michelle Tait, 14 yrs old.
